text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Contacting the IRS Employee Assistance and Worklife Referral Program (EAP) SAMPLE Sample Sample

) This IRM provides broad policy and guidance on the IRS Employee and Work-life Referral (EAP) Program. It further provides definitions of terms and agreements. The IRS EAP is designed to help an employee deal with any personal, family or job related concern that could interfere with mance or conduct at work. (

) Federal agencies have the authority to establish health services for the promotion and maintenance of the physical and mental fitness of employees the Federal Government. The EAP falls under this authority. The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) recognizes the importance of its employees and realizes employees may experience a wide range issues impacting their worklife balance, families, health/wellness, or job performance. On a basis, employees may freely use the EAP for access to resources and tools, confidential counseling, health coaches, legal or financial services. (

) The EAP is a formal, non-disciplinary program designed to assist employees and their immediate families in a variety of issues—mental, emotional, financial, legal, drug and alcohol abuse, etc.,— that may adversely affect an employee’s job performance and personal life. Assistance is provided through consultation, evaluation, counseling, and/or referral to community resources and treatment facilities. Work-life referral services are available to help employees find solutions to the daily challenges of personal, work and family issues. Employees may use work-life concierge services to answer questions on finding child care, finding housing, managing financial legal guidance or figuring out how to take care of an aging parent who might live far way. (
) Health services for Federal employees are authorized by Public Law
These services are provided to promote the physical and mental fitness of Federal employees. The authority for substance abuse programs is found in: Sec.

, require Federal agencies to establish appropriate prevention, treatment, and rehabilitative programs and services for alcohol and drug abuse issues Federal civilian employees and to report annually to Congress on these programs (

) This IRM provides broad policy and guidance on the IRS Employee and Work-life Referral (EAP) Program. It further provides definitions of unique Purpose terms and agreements. The IRS EAP is designed to help an employee deal with any personal, family or job related concern that could interfere with mance or conduct at work. (

) Federal agencies have the authority to establish health services for the promotion and maintenance of the physical and mental fitness of employees the Federal Government. The EAP falls under this authority. The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) recognizes the importance of its employees and realizes employees may experience a wide range issues impacting their worklife balance, families, health/wellness, or job performance. On a voluntary basis, employees may freely use the EAP for access to resources and tools, confidential counseling, health coaches, legal or financial services. (

) The EAP is a formal, non-disciplinary program designed to assist employees and their immediate families in a variety of issues—mental, emotional, financial, legal, drug and alcohol abuse, etc.,— that may adversely affect both an employee’s job performance and personal life. Assistance is provided through consultation, evaluation, counseling, and/or referral to community resources and treatment facilities. Work-life referral services are available to help employees find solutions to the daily challenges of personal, work and family issues. Employees may use work-life concierge services to answer questions on finding child care, finding housing, managing financial stressors, legal guidance or figuring out how to take care of an aging parent who might live far way. (
) Health services for Federal employees are authorized by Public Law
These services are provided to promote the physical and mental fitness of Federal employees. The authority for substance abuse programs is found in:

family issues. Employees may use work-life concierge services to answer questions on finding child care, finding housing, managing financial legal guidance or figuring out how to take care of an aging parent who live far way. Health services for Federal employees are authorized by Public Law These services are provided to promote the physical and mental fitness Federal employees. The authority for substance abuse programs is found Sec.
of the Public Health Services Act by Sec.

authorized agencies to provide services, to the extent feasible, to family members of employees who alcohol and drug issues, and to employees with family members who substance abuse issues. Public Law
, The Federal Employee Substance Abuse Education Treatment Act of

, require Federal agencies to establish appropriate prevention, and rehabilitative programs and services for alcohol and drug abuse Federal civilian employees and to report annually to Congress on these programs (
(law authorizes health programs for Federal employees).
(law mandates EAPs for employee alcohol and drug
(regulation-confidentiality of alcohol and drug abuse patient records). (

requires agencies to establish drug-free Federal workplace programs, including an Employee Assistance Program (EAP) as essential element in achieving a drug-free workforce. Agencies must refer all employees found to be using illegal drugs to the EAP for assessment, ing, and referral for treatment or rehabilitation, as appropriate. Additional information is available on the Employee Resource Center (ERC): (
) Alcohol/Drug Abuse - The excessive use of alcohol or drugs in a manner may impair a person’s physical, mental, emotional, interpersonal, and economic functioning. (

) Assessment - An ongoing process or evaluation in which professional expertise and skills are exercised to collect and analyze data, which in eration with the client, results in identifying, defining and prioritizing the physical, mental, and social issues, issues or challenges. An assessment provides for an accurate diagnosis of the client and the basis for a treatment issue solving plan. (

) Client - An individual who is eligible to receive EAP services, as defined by agency policy or contract requirements. A client might include an employee the employee’s spouse, dependent child, parent, domestic partner, or a (who meets the requirements of Section
) Community Resources - Organizations such as treatment and facilities and programs that exist in the community, such as Alcoholics Anonymous and other self-help groups. (

) Critical Incident - An event, usually sudden, unexpected and potentially threatening, “in which a person experiences a trauma, i.e., feels by a sense of personal vulnerability and/or lack of control. Examples of a critical incident are a natural disaster, serious workplace accident, a hostage situation or violence in the workplace.” (

) Critical Incident Stress Management (CISM) - The constellation of or activities that may be used by an organization to respond to and manage critical incident. Services include, but are not limited to, debriefings, to the workforce, anniversary responses, etc. A critical incident debriefing is meeting or series of meetings held with the workgroup following a critical incident. (
) Drug Free Workplace Program (DFWP) - Those laws, regulations and policies emanating from Executive Order (EO)
, and subsequently the Drug Free Workplace Act of

, that ordered employees to refrain from using illegal drugs, whether on or off duty. It mandates that the head of each Executive agency shall develop a plan for achieving the objective of a drug-free workplace. Elements of the plan establishing a program to test for the use of illegal drugs by employees in sensitive positions; training for managers and employees; and establishment EAPs that emphasize high-level direction, education, counseling, referral to rehabilitation, and coordination with available resources. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
42 CFR Part 2 (regulation-confidentiality of alcohol and drug abuse patient

) Emotional/ Behavioral Issues - issues, such as financial, family, marital issues, etc., that may have an adverse impact on employee performance, conduct, or reliability. Personal issues may impair job performance. Such issues may include financial or marital difficulties, psychiatric or physical illnesses, drug and/or alcohol abuse, death of a family member, etc., and stemming from personal issues of another person, such as a supervisor, co- worker, or a spouse. (

) Employee Assistance Program - An EAP is a worksite-based program designed to assist in the identification and resolution of work-related and work-related issues associated with employees impaired by personal including, but not limited to health, marital, family, financial, alcohol, drug, emotional or other personal concerns which may adversely affect employee performance. (
) External EAP Service Provider - A company external to the agency EAP services on a contractual basis. (
) Family Member - Any member of the employee’s immediate household who a dependent and/or spouse/domestic partner who shares financial and caretaking responsibilities. (

) Management Consults - Expert advice given to leaders, supervisors, resources and/or union representatives regarding the management of or actual performance and conduct concerns. One example is coaching a pervisor on how to refer an employee to the EAP. (

) Management Referral - Referrals to the EAP that are initiated by an ee’s manager/supervisor because of performance or conduct concerns. referrals can be oral or in writing and are not considered disciplinary actions. (
) Presenting Issues - The personal concern or issue as described by the client prior to assessment by the EAP professional. (
) Release of Information - A document signed and dated by a client, giving EAP (counselor) permission to release specific information about the client, a person outside of the EAP. (

) Safe Harbor - A self-referral option which allows any employee to step and identify him/herself as an illegal drug user for the purpose of entering a drug treatment program under the EAP. Safe Harbor allows employees to rehabilitative assistance from the agency EAP in accordance with Executive Order
prior to being identified through other means. (
) Self Referral - An employee who voluntarily seeks EAP assistance or who seeks EAP assistance at the recommendation of a union representative, co- worker, friend, family member, nurse, etc. (
) Session - A meeting between an EAP counselor and client, usually lasting to
) Short-term Counseling/Treatment - Services provided by the EAP to the employee/client for approximately

sessions. When counseling is required beyond the number of sessions originally provided, the EAP is expected to ensure the employee is referred to a Federal Employees Benefit (FEHB) plan or additional community resources. Internal Revenue Manual

Short-term Counseling/Treatment - Services provided by the EAP counselor to the employee/client for approximately 1 to 4 sessions. When counseling is required beyond the number of sessions originally provided, the EAP counselor is expected to ensure the employee is referred to a Federal Employees Health Benefit (FEHB) plan or additional community resources.
) Work-life - Consist of practices, policies and programs that support the of everyone in the workforce to achieve success at work and at home. (

) The IRS Employee Assistance and Work-Life Referral Program is a voluntary, confidential counseling and referral service provided to all employees and immediate family members. “Immediate Family Members” is defined as members of the immediate household who are dependents and/or spouses/ domestic partners who share financial and family caretaking responsibilities. IRS employees who separate (e.g., retirement, voluntary separation, involun- tary separation) from the IRS as a result of agency technology, restructuring, and workforce initiatives are also eligible for six (
) Participation in the EAP is voluntary and confidential and will not jeopardize employee’s job security or promotional opportunities. (
) The IRS EAP offers short-term counseling and referral services for a variety issues such as mental health, emotional, family, financial, elder and care, legal difficulties, etc. (

) There is no cost to employees or family members who receive counseling other services provided directly by EAP. There are times when it is to refer employees and/or family members to outside community resources or their Federal Employees Health Benefit (FEHB) plan. When employees these referrals, they are responsible for the fees charged by the facility health plan. The EAP works with employees and/or their family members to keep the cost within their financial means. (

) EAP counseling helps employees identify and assess issue(s) and also helps employees in issue solving. EAP provides employees with a maximum of four counseling sessions per issue, per calendar year [i.e., for each issue an employee may receive

) All counseling is strictly confidential. The confidentiality of all employees and managers in consultation and debriefings will be adhered to as required the Privacy Act, Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA) and Disclosure Laws. Client information may not be released to anyone without their prior written consent, except as required by law. (
) Employees can contact the EAP directly. Their contact, participation in the and any recommended treatment is confidential and will not be disclosed to the organization. (

) No penalty may be imposed upon an employee for accepting or declining to participate in the EAP. The fundamental purpose of the EAP is to enable employees to achieve their full individual potential, even when stress and issues in their working or personal lives present difficult challenges. (

) EAP will make referral, where appropriate, to a community service or profes- sional resource that provides treatment and/or rehabilitation. With the exception of illness or injury directly resulting from employment and able under the Federal Employees’ Compensation Act (FECA), medical care and treatment are personal to the employee and, therefore, payment may not be made from appropriated funds unless provided for in a contract of employ- ment or by statute or by regulation. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
Work-life - Consist of practices, policies and programs that support the efforts of everyone in the workforce to achieve success at work and at home.

) All employees of the IRS are considered partners of the EAP and are aged to support the program’s objectives and philosophy. Employees are encouraged to utilize the EAP when they have issues of a personal nature related to work and family. (
) Management may utilize the EAP to assist employees who may need in handling personal concerns and to help with organizational issues that be affecting the mental health of employees. (
) Unions are also regarded as partners of the EAP and whenever appropriate, may support the objectives and policy of the EAP. (
) The Employee Assistance and Work-life Referral Program helps employees and their immediate family members resolve personal and work-related Components The program has two main components: (
) Work-life Referral Services. In addition, the Program offers additional support and services to the agency. (

) The EAP provides telephonic and in-person clinical services to help and their immediate family members address stressful life issues and Assistance concerns. The program is available to IRS employees and their families,

days per year. Employees may meet in person with a counselor in their community or with a member of the EAP telephone counseling staff. Employees are entitled to a maximum of four seling sessions per calendar year for each presenting issue (

sessions for stress, etc.). If further counseling is needed after the session EAP limit, EAP counselors will assist employees in arranging care through their own health insurance plan or other community resources. Sessions with an EAP counselor can be over the telephone from the office and/or home or in person with a local therapist. The EAP can help address a variety of concerns, including: (cid:

) If an employee is dissatisfied with the professional counseling (either tele- phonic or face-to-face sessions) received, they have the option of seeing another counselor (at no additional cost or loss of counseling sessions) until the EAP service is provided satisfactorily. Employees are referred to the telephone counselor for each call unless otherwise requested by the (

) Managers who have concerns about a specific employee whose conduct or personal issues are affecting his or her performance and the performance of the work group can call the EAP to request a management consultation. Specially trained consultants will help managers refer their employees encing issues to the EAP.

) Work-life Referral Services help employees find solutions to the daily chal- lenges of personal, work, and family life through consultation and referral to local and community resources. The program provides information and to assist with life events of all kinds. For concerns ranging from workplace stress to caring for a young child or an elderly relative, employees have access to a wide variety of resources to help manage their work-life balance. Work-life consultants address a variety of concerns, including: Family Issues
) Finding quality care for an elderly (cid:
Confidential access is available to legal professionals who are dedicated to providing practical, understandable information and assistance to assist employees in resolving legal issues, including:

Financial professionals are available to discuss concerns and provide employees with the tools and information needed to meet financial goals. Employees may consult with financial specialists about personal money agement questions and receive the information needed to make the best decisions on issues, such as:

) Estate planning On-line information and research services Expert information, resources and referrals on behavioral health, care, and legal or financial matters are available via the internet at the EAP service provider’s (contractor’s) website. (

) The EAP/Work-life Program provides formal and informal training (e.g. employee orientations, webinars, workshops, brown bag lunches, groups, manager training, union briefings, wellness and educational that encourage referral to the program: (cid:
) Orientation sessions to introduce employees to the Employee Work-life Program and its provisions.
(cid:129) Orientation sessions to introduce employees to the Employee Assistance/ Work-life Program and its provisions.

) Manager training sessions to provide managers with knowledge on how use EAP services and how to use the critical incident and referral for job performance issues. Also provides management training in to work setting changes—change management, redeployment, workplace stressors—by request of managers for their work groups. (cid:
) Wellness sessions to provide employees with ways to identify issues, encourage help seeking issue resolutions and offer insight and relief from issues by directing them in some cases to EAP. (cid:
) Wellness educational sessions to provide information on specific informa- tion on specific topics, e.g., dealing with stress, conflict resolution, managing change, diet, exercise, etc. (cid:
) Education and counseling to employees in partnership with the IRS Smoking Cessation Program. (cid:

) Drug free workplace training/education for employees and managers in partnership with the IRS Drug Free Workplace Program (DFWP). Note: Employees should coordinate participation during business hours with their managers. The sessions are training and management may allow tive time for employees to attend. (

) Critical Incident Stress Management Services are available to impacted IRS workgroups. CISMS are available to IRS work groups affected by a critical incident. Examples of critical incidents include deaths, serious injuries, incidents involving children or co-workers, personal assaults, industrial accidents, etc. Managers may contact the EAP directly to arrange for critical incident services. These debriefings usually involve three or more EAP specialists help managers develop an action plan to respond to a incident. This can include on-site debriefings as well as counseling services. (

) EAP Transition counseling services provide support to IRS employees impacted by reduction in force (RIF), technology and organizational changes. Transition Counselors are available at formal meetings/briefings to assist employees as needed. Transition counseling services must be ordered the IRS EAP Program Manager. (
) EAP provides telephonic one-on-one wellness coaching to help employees toward lifestyle changes such as: (cid:

) Weight management Note: Wellness coaching is at no cost to employees. Services are available non-business hours and business hours. Employees must have manager approval to participate during business hours.

) Manager training sessions to provide managers with knowledge on how use EAP services and how to use the critical incident and referral for job performance issues. Also provides management training in to work setting changes—change management, redeployment, workplace stressors—by request of managers for their work groups. (cid:
) Wellness sessions to provide employees with ways to identify issues, encourage help seeking issue resolutions and offer insight and relief from issues by directing them in some cases to EAP. (cid:
) Wellness educational sessions to provide information on specific informa- tion on specific topics, e.g., dealing with stress, conflict resolution, managing change, diet, exercise, etc. (cid:
) Education and counseling to employees in partnership with the IRS Smoking Cessation Program. (cid:
) Drug free workplace training/education for employees and managers in partnership with the IRS Drug Free Workplace Program (DFWP).
Note: Employees should coordinate participation during business hours with their managers. The sessions are training and management may allow administra- tive time for employees to attend.

Critical Incident Stress Management Services are available to impacted IRS workgroups. CISMS are available to IRS work groups affected by a critical incident. Examples of critical incidents include deaths, serious injuries, incidents involving children or co

workers, personal assaults, industrial accidents, etc. Managers may contact the EAP directly to arrange for critical incident services. These debriefings usually involve three or more employees. EAP specialists help managers develop an action plan to respond to a specific incident. This can include on
site debriefings as well as counseling services.
EAP provides telephonic one-on-one wellness coaching to help employees toward lifestyle changes such as:
Wellness coaching is at no cost to employees. Services are available during non-business hours and business hours. Employees must have manager approval to participate during business hours.

) Administrative leave may be granted to an employee for participation in the agency’s EAP. Managers may grant administrative leave for visiting the EAP during duty hours. Employees may be granted up to one hour of excused absence, plus travel time, if applicable for the four free EAP sessions only. If manager grants administrative leave for visiting the EAP during duty hours, manager may request, with the employee’s written permission, proof of dance at the counseling session. Confirmation of attendance will be by the EAP according to applicable confidentiality procedures. (

) Employees must request and coordinate scheduling of an appointment duty hours with their manager. Employees who do not want their managers know of their attendance must arrange appointments outside official duty or while on official leave. During any period(s) of treatment and rehabilitation through an outside resource, employees must request to use their own or sick leave or request leave without pay in accordance with applicable rules and regulations. (
) Administrative leave may also be granted for EAP employee orientation or education activities (e.g., general orientations, webinars, etc.). (
a) covers all EAP records. In addition, EAP records of clients with alcohol and drug issues are protected further by
, Confidentiality of Alcohol and Drug Abuse Patient Records. (
) EAP counselors must provide employees with a written notice concerning confidential nature of EAP records along with the conditions where discussed in counseling may be disclosed. (

) Depending on the location of the counseling site and the professional back- ground of the EAP counselor, the EAP records may also be protected by and professional licensing/credentialing laws and regulations. Generally, laws and regulations prohibit EAP staff from sharing any information about clients to anyone outside of the EAP, without the specific written consent of client. (

) Employee participation in the EAP is confidential and strictly voluntary. However, if a manager or union steward recommends an employee seek assistance, then, with the employee’s written permission, the manager or steward can be notified as whether or not the employee attended the and request an assessment of how much work time will be needed for ing counseling or rehabilitation. The counselor cannot discuss any additional information because that information is covered by the Privacy Act. (

) All records of the EAP, whether written, oral and electronic are covered by policy. This applies to records generated and/or maintained by IRS who are EAP staff or contractual EAP staff. The contractor is responsible for maintaining confidential records on clients and these records must be main- tained in a system of records. (

) Only those individuals working directly with the program’s clients have to EAP client records. Additionally, the agency EAP National Program may have access to the records for the purposes of: (cid:
) Destroying EAP records at the end of their period of maintenance. (cid:
) Transferring EAP records from one contractor to another. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

The Privacy Act (5 U.S.C. 552a) covers all EAP records. In addition, EAP records of clients with alcohol and drug issues are protected further by 42 CFR ″ ″ 2 Part 2, Confidentiality of Alcohol and Drug Abuse Patient Records.

Employee participation in the EAP is confidential and strictly voluntary. However, if a manager or union steward recommends an employee seek EAP assistance, then, with the employee’s written permission, the manager or union steward can be notified as whether or not the employee attended the session and request an assessment of how much work time will be needed for continu- ing counseling or rehabilitation. The counselor cannot discuss any additional information because that information is covered by the Privacy Act.

) Contractors are custodians of EAP records while under contract to the All EAP records are the property of the Internal Revenue Service, including Ownership those generated and/or maintained by contractors. At the completion of any contract, EAP records still in existence will be surrendered by the to designated persons in IRS (i.e., the EAP National Program Manager) or be transferred to another contractor with the express permission and instruc- tions from IRS staff responsible for the records. (

) The laws and regulations governing the EAP should not be construed to authorize any violation of state law, in the event that a state law has greater to State restrictions than these regulations. Also, no state law may either authorize or and Other compel any disclosures prohibited by these regulations. (

) Confidentiality safeguards for records stored electronically must be EAP data systems shall be protected from entry by anyone outside the EAP. Record Contractors must ensure the security, privacy and confidentiality of all elec- tronic protected health information as required by law (Privacy Act and (

) Records are retained for three years after the employee has ceased contact with the EAP, whether or not the employee has terminated employment with of Maintenance the agency. Records may be kept longer if required by the State where the records are kept, or until any litigation involving the employee is resolved. When applicable, contract staff may retain records past this period, for as as any relevant state statutes of limitation require. All EAP files shall be destroyed after the required period of maintenance. (
) Employees who utilize EAP services will be informed about disclosure and procedures. (

) In certain situations, information provided to the EAP is not protected by the confidentiality regulations and policies and, due to the nature of the informa- Covered tion, must be reported to the appropriate people. The situations are: and (cid:

, the EAP is required by law to report incidents of suspected child abuse and neglect (in some states, elder and spouse abuse) to the appropriate state and local authorities. These disclosures limited to information about the abuse. (cid:

) If the client commits or threatens to commit a crime that would physically harm someone or cause substantial property damage, disclosures may made to appropriate persons, such as law enforcement authorities. (

) In some cases, employees are referred to the EAP by supervisors because work performance and/or conduct issues. Except as discussed above, no mation will be released to supervisors without the employee’s written regardless of the nature of the referral. Employees are not compelled to release personal and/or health information to supervisors. When they to do so, they will sign a consent form allowing the release of such When consent is given to disclose the information to supervisors, the EAP usually limit its discussion to:
) other (if other information being requested, it must be specified). (

) However, there may be instances where it will be in the employee’s best interests to sign a release of information, e.g., when an employee is seeking accommodation for a certain physical or emotional issue or as part of a last chance agreement. Another example might be when an employee is in a potential disciplinary situation and wishes to demonstrate his or her sincerity in seeking assistance with the issue. Based on this information regarding an employee’s involvement in the Employee Assistance Program, supervisor might decide to hold a disciplinary action in abeyance pending a positive change in the employee’s performance and/or conduct. (

) As with all other releases of information, the EAP requires the employee’s written consents in order to share any information with human resources, relations, and union representatives, etc. Relations and and Who Work (

) Any information disclosed with the employee’s consent must be by a statement that prohibits further disclosure unless the consent expressly permits further disclosures. A sample form for this purpose that meets the quirements of
It shall be to any written information released or sent separately if the information was released orally.

, the EAP is required by law to report incidents of suspected child abuse and neglect (in some states, elder and spouse abuse) to the appropriate state and local authorities. These disclosures are limited to information about the abuse. (cid:

(05-29-2013) Releases of Information to and from Supervisors and Managers

Any information disclosed with the employee’s consent must be accompanied by a statement that prohibits further disclosure unless the consent expressly permits further disclosures. A sample form for this purpose that meets the re- quirements of
It shall be attached to any written information released or sent separately if the information was released orally.

) Self-Referrals—Self-referrals occur at the employee’s own initiative. When employee recognizes a issue with alcohol, drugs or emotional stress that is affecting work performance and would like help, he or she may contact the EAP provider. No one is notified of the employee’s participation in EAP services, unless the employee requests that a third party be notified. (

) Management Referrals—If a manager observes certain patterns of behavior and/or work performance issues, or has some other reason to believe that EAP could provide needed assistance to an employee, he or she may make an offer of the EAP services to the employee. The manager should not to diagnose the perceived issue, nor should they counsel the employee on personal issues. Managers should support the use of IRS EAP by their employees. Managers should not try to counsel the employee on personal issues. The EAP counselor is better equipped to help an employee who is periencing personal issues. The employee has the option to refuse the and the employee cannot be disciplined for lack of participation in EAP services. (
) Mandatory Referral—A referral by the manager to the EAP for an positive drug test or who is identified as using or abusing drugs in with Executive Order

This type of referral is in writing, and the EAP counselor should receives a referral memo addressed to the EAP. While this referral to the EAP is mandatory, there is no authority or requirement to an employee to partake of EAP services, which are voluntary. Failure to do however, may have adverse consequences for the employee. See Exhibit
for sample release of information form for a mandatory referral. (

) Referrals from Others—Union representatives, employee health units, resource staff, etc. may also refer employees to the EAP. They will be that written consent must be obtained from a referred employee before EAP will proceed with the referral. (

) A variety of other outside programs and resources (e.g. Alcoholics Domestic Violence Hotline) are available for recommendation to employees and family members. EAP counselors maintain a current list of community programs and resources, and assist with initial arrangements and appoint- ments. The cost of any such programs or resources is borne by the if it is not covered by the employee’s health insurance. In cases for which pitalization is recommended, the employee may request sick leave, leave without pay, annual leave, or advanced sick leave in accordance with appli- cable law, rules and regulations. (
) One of the programs that partners with the EAP is the IRS Drug Free Workplace Program. The Drug Free Workplace Program was established in response to Executive Order

and its’ implementing legislation. The program is intended to assist employees with concerns related to drug abuse as well as help assure that IRS maintains an environment free of drugs. The IRS developed the Drug Free Workplace Plan to set forth the objectives, policies, and procedures for implementation and operation of the program. IRS EAP was given a number of responsibilities in the Drug Free Workplace Plan. They are:
) to assist supervisors and managers in dealing with the sequences of their employees’ illegal drug use and
) to assist employees in their efforts to overcome current drug use and refrain from future use. The EAP will provide its regular services in response to these objectives. Internal Revenue Manual

) Self-Referrals—Self-referrals occur at the employee’s own initiative. When an employee recognizes a issue with alcohol, drugs or emotional stress that is to EAP affecting work performance and would like help, he or she may contact the EAP provider. No one is notified of the employee’s participation in EAP services, unless the employee requests that a third party be notified. (

) Management Referrals—If a manager observes certain patterns of behavior and/or work performance issues, or has some other reason to believe that the EAP could provide needed assistance to an employee, he or she may make an offer of the EAP services to the employee. The manager should not to diagnose the perceived issue, nor should they counsel the employee on personal issues. Managers should support the use of IRS EAP by their employees. Managers should not try to counsel the employee on personal issues. The EAP counselor is better equipped to help an employee who is ex- periencing personal issues. The employee has the option to refuse the and the employee cannot be disciplined for lack of participation in EAP services. (
) Mandatory Referral—A referral by the manager to the EAP for an employee’s positive drug test or who is identified as using or abusing drugs in accordance with Executive Order

This type of referral is in writing, and the EAP counselor should receives a referral memo addressed to the EAP. While this referral to the EAP is mandatory, there is no authority or requirement to an employee to partake of EAP services, which are voluntary. Failure to do so, however, may have adverse consequences for the employee. See Exhibit
for sample release of information form for a mandatory referral. (

) Referrals from Others—Union representatives, employee health units, human resource staff, etc. may also refer employees to the EAP. They will be that written consent must be obtained from a referred employee before EAP will proceed with the referral. (
) A variety of other outside programs and resources (e.g. Alcoholics
(10-07-2011) Relationship with IRS Drug Free Workplace Program

) Any employee found to be using illegal drugs may be referred to the EAP. EAP is administered separately from the drug testing program, and is and Availability to all employees without regard to a finding of drug use. The EAP provides counseling or referral for rehabilitation, as well as education and training regarding illegal drug use. The EAP is available not only to Service but when feasible, to the families of employees with drug issues, and to employees with family members who have drug issues. (

) Employees may also self-identify as illegal drug users to management under the Safe Harbor provision in the IRS Drug Free Workplace Plan. This with Safe protects employees from disciplinary actions that may otherwise be taken Provisions against employees found to be using drugs illegally. These employees must voluntarily admit their drug use before being identified through other means; must complete counseling/rehabilitation as determined and monitored by the EAP (or other counseling/rehabilitation entity), agree to random follow-up testing and must not use drugs again. The Safe Harbor provision cannot protect employees from disciplinary actions or random testing if they refuse to notify their supervisors that they are seeking help for their drug issues. It also cannot protect employees who have been found to use drugs illegally a second time. (
) In partnership with the DFWP, the EAP provides on-going drug education for employees and supervisors. Education and Training (

) The IRS Drug Free Workplace Plan includes provisions for testing of employees for illegal drug use. The EAP is not responsible for the with Drug tion or operation of the drug testing program, but will provide counseling and

identify as illegal drug users to management under the Safe Harbor provision in the IRS Drug Free Workplace Plan. This provision protects employees from disciplinary actions that may otherwise be taken against employees found to be using drugs illegally. These employees must voluntarily admit their drug use before being identified through other means; must complete counseling/rehabilitation as determined and monitored by the EAP (or other counseling/rehabilitation entity), agree to random follow

up drug testing and must not use drugs again. To contact the IRS Employee Assistance and Work-Life Program simply dial the toll-free number 1-800- 977-7631 (TDD: 800-697-0353). A counselor is available to speak with you 24 hours a day.

Below is a list of the International Toll Free Numbers that can be accessed by IRS employees globally. These numbers will link you directly to an Employee Assistance and Work-Life Referral Program spe- cialist. In the event that there is not a toll free number for your specific location, you can dial 1-312-595- 0074 (collect internationally) and you will be linked to the Employee Assistance and Work-life Referral Program. If you encounter difficulties with any of the toll-free numbers, please use the 1-312-595-0074 collect number.

With Internet access, you can research a topic before seeking professional help. Go online to receive expert information, resources and referrals on behavioral health, dependent care, and legal or financial matters. To access Guidance Resources OnlineSM just click www.guidanceresources.com, Guidance Resources Online log on as a new user and enter our IRS ID (IRS112) when prompted. Register yourself as a first time user and then select your own user name and password. Once registered, access the site anytime using the user name and password you selected.
